verses.text: In the year that King Uzziah died, I saw the Lord sitting on a high and exalted throne, and the hem of His robe filled the temple.
verses.comment: Isaiah's vision begins with God's majesty revealed in the temple. The glory filling the temple can be seen as prefiguring the fullness of God's dwelling among His people and foreshadowing Christ’s incarnation (see John 12:41, where John relates Isaiah’s vision directly to Jesus).

verses.text: Above Him stood seraphim. Each had six wings: with two they covered their faces, with two they covered their feet, and with two they flew.
verses.comment: The seraphim are a special order of angels attending God's throne. Their posture shows reverence, humility, and readiness to serve. This angelic worship is reflected in heavenly visions in Revelation, linking Old and New Testament imagery.

verses.text: And one called to another and said: 'Holy, holy, holy is the LORD of hosts; all the earth is full of His glory.'
verses.comment: This triple declaration of God's holiness emphasizes His absolute purity and transcendence. The liturgical phrase 'Holy, holy, holy' is used in worship, prefiguring Christian liturgy and the Trinitarian understanding of God.

verses.text: The doorposts shook at the sound of their voices, and the temple was filled with smoke.
verses.comment: The shaking and smoke recall God’s presence at Sinai and during temple worship, signifying His awesome power and holiness. The imagery invokes both historical and spiritual realities of God's majesty.

verses.text: Then I said, 'Woe is me! I am ruined, for I am a man of unclean lips, living among a people of unclean lips; for my eyes have seen the King, the LORD of hosts!'
verses.comment: Encountering God's holiness leads Isaiah to deep awareness of his own sinfulness. This pattern of recognizing sin before encountering grace recurs throughout Scripture and underscores the need for purification before approaching God.

verses.text: Then one of the seraphim flew to me, holding a burning coal taken with tongs from the altar.
verses.comment: The altar represents the place of sacrifice and atonement, closely tied to worship and the forgiveness of sins. The burning coal symbolizes cleansing and purification by a divine act.

verses.text: He touched my mouth with it and said: 'See, this has touched your lips; your guilt is taken away and your sin is atoned for.'
verses.comment: Isaiah is purified through a direct act from heaven, prefiguring sacramental cleansing, and highlighting that forgiveness comes through God's initiative. The concept of atonement here foreshadows Christ’s redemptive sacrifice.

verses.text: Then I heard the voice of the Lord saying, 'Whom shall I send, and who will go for Us?' And I said, 'Here I am; send me.'
verses.comment: God’s question reveals a divine commission. Isaiah’s willing response models the calling of prophets and apostles, and even believers who answer God's invitation to service. The plural 'Us' hints at the mystery within God’s unity, anticipating fuller revelation in the New Testament.

verses.text: He said, 'Go and say to this people: Listen carefully, but do not understand; look closely, but do not perceive.'
verses.comment: God’s message includes judgment: spiritual blindness as a consequence of persistent sin. These words are quoted by Jesus about those who resist the Gospel, showing continuity between Old and New Testament warnings.

verses.text: Make the heart of this people dull, and their ears heavy, and blind their eyes; lest they see with their eyes, hear with their ears, understand with their heart, and turn and be healed.
verses.comment: This hardening is both a judgment and a mystery, showing how God’s sovereignty coexists with human freedom. Healing comes through conversion, pointing to the need for repentance and sacramental restoration.

verses.text: Then I said, 'How long, Lord?' And He answered, 'Until cities lie in ruins, without inhabitant, houses without people, and the land is devastated and abandoned.'
verses.comment: God reveals the extent of coming judgment and exile. Yet the question 'how long?' subtly points to a hope for restoration, fulfilled through God's faithfulness even after discipline.

verses.text: The LORD will drive people far away, and abandonment will be great in the midst of the land.
verses.comment: The exile is part of God's discipline, but it also foreshadows mercy and restoration for a remnant, a recurring theme in salvation history.

verses.text: But even if a tenth remains in it, it will be burned again. As a terebinth or an oak tree whose stump remains when felled, the holy seed is its stump.
verses.comment: Despite judgment, a holy remnant remains—the 'holy seed.' This stump imagery alludes to hope: from this remnant arises the messianic promise (see Isa. 11:1), ultimately fulfilled in Christ and the enduring family of believers united in worship and faith across generations.
